title: THE SECRET SCOUT: Southampton youngster Callum Slattery looks like captain material
text:
Our scout is a top football expert who attends matches each week searching for the next star.

This week Sportsmail's Secret Scout places Southampton's Callum Slattery under the microscope...

Callum Slattery joined Southampton in 2008 and has made five first-team appearances

CALLUM SLATTERY CV Club: Southampton Age: 20 Club: Midfielder Value: £500,000

WHAT HAS HE GOT?

Watching Slattery in an Under 23 game made me consider that he might have qualities which need greater testing. Though not in a strong side, he controlled Southampton's possession from a deep midfield position in front of three tall, tough defenders.

He did not appear to be the kind of holding midfielder whose first thought was to loan the ball to his defenders and get it back. I liked the way he looked forwards and was prepared to play the occasional risky ball.

He was hoping his front-runners would give him the opportunity to play penetrating balls and showed a range of passing. Right-footed, he was rarely caught out when in possession.

When he did get robbed he was quick to recover and chase hard, tackling back and conceding a free-kick — 'One for the team', as they say.

The midfielder made his first-team debut in January and has a big future ahead of him

Minutes later another mistimed touch on the edge of the box should have seen him yellow-carded but tackling was not a downside.

He won nearly all his confrontations. Talking to his colleagues, encouraging and showing some presence, he kept midfield well balanced.

When surrounded and taken heavily to ground he was quick to get to his feet, showing physicality and bravery. He looks captain material. Indeed in this game it was mainly through his prompting, encouragement and leadership that his team clawed back a two-goal deficit to draw.

WHAT DOES HE NEED?

Perhaps he could have played further forwards in the formation, where he would probably have made more chances than in this deep position where he had more time and space to play.

In one attack he hit a cannon of a shot which was deflected for a corner, suggesting once again that in a more forward midfield position he has scoring potential.

It will be interesting to see his development. Southampton have a history of accelerating youth and in many cases capitalising in the transfer market. The coaches there will know his qualities and I will watch closely how they handle him.
